name: London - The White Man's Way
body:
âTo cook by your fire and to sleep under your roof for
the night,â I had announced on entering old Ebbitsâs
cabin; and he had looked at me blear-eyed and vacuous, while
Zilla had favored me with a sour face and a contemptuous
grunt.Â  Zilla was his wife, and no more bitter-tongued,
implacable old squaw dwelt on the Yukon.Â  Nor would I have
stopped there had my dogs been less tired or had the rest of the
village been inhabited.Â  But this cabin alone had I found
occupied, and in this cabin, perforce, I took my shelter.
Old Ebbits now and again pulled his tangled wits together, and
hints and sparkles of intelligence came and went in his
eyes.Â  Several times during the preparation of my supper he
even essayed hospitable inquiries about my health, the condition
and number of my dogs, and the distance I had travelled that
day.Â  And each time Zilla had looked sourer than ever and
grunted more contemptuously.
Yet I confess that there was no particular call for
cheerfulness on their part.Â  There they crouched by the
fire, the pair of them, at the end of their days, old and
withered and helpless, racked by rheumatism, bitten by hunger,
and tantalized by the frying-odors of my abundance of meat.Â 
They rocked back and forth in a slow and hopeless way, and
regularly, once every five minutes, Ebbits emitted a low
groan.Â  It was not so much a groan of pain, as of
pain-weariness.Â  He was oppressed by the weight and the
torment of this thing called life, and still more was he
oppressed by the fear of death.Â  His was that eternal
tragedy of the aged, with whom the joy of life has departed and
the instinct for death has not come.
When my moose-meat spluttered rowdily in the frying-pan, I
noticed old Ebbitsâs nostrils twitch and distend as he
caught the food-scent.Â  He ceased rocking for a space and
forgot to groan, while a look of intelligence seemed to come into
his face.
Zilla, on the other hand, rocked more rapidly, and for the
first time, in sharp little yelps, voiced her pain.Â  It came
to me that their behavior was like that of hungry dogs, and in
the fitness of things I should not have been astonished had Zilla
suddenly developed a tail and thumped it on the floor in right
doggish fashion.Â  Ebbits drooled a little and stopped his
rocking very frequently to lean forward and thrust his tremulous
nose nearer to the source of gustatory excitement.
When I passed them each a plate of the fried meat, they ate
greedily, making loud mouth-noisesâchampings of worn teeth
and sucking intakes of the breath, accompanied by a continuous
spluttering and mumbling.Â  After that, when I gave them each
a mug of scalding tea, the noises ceased.Â  Easement and
content came into their faces.Â  Zilla relaxed her sour mouth
long enough to sigh her satisfaction.Â  Neither rocked any
more, and they seemed to have fallen into placid
meditation.Â  Then a dampness came into Ebbitsâs eyes,
and I knew that the sorrow of self-pity was his.Â  The search
required to find their pipes told plainly that they had been
without tobacco a long time, and the old manâs eagerness
for the narcotic rendered him helpless, so that I was compelled
to light his pipe for him.
âWhy are you all alone in the village?â I
asked.Â  âIs everybody dead?Â  Has there been a
great sickness?Â  Are you alone left of the
living?â
Old Ebbits shook his head, saying:Â  âNay, there has
been no great sickness.Â  The village has gone away to hunt
meat.Â  We be too old, our legs are not strong, nor can our
backs carry the burdens of camp and trail.Â  Wherefore we
remain here and wonder when the young men will return with
meat.â
âWhat if the young men do return with meat?â Zilla
demanded harshly.
âThey may return with much meat,â he quavered
hopefully.
âEven so, with much meat,â she continued, more
harshly than before.Â  âBut of what worth to you and
me?Â  A few bones to gnaw in our toothless old age.Â  But
the back-fat, the kidneys, and the tonguesâthese shall go
into other mouths than thine and mine, old man.â
Ebbits nodded his head and wept silently.
âThere be no one to hunt meat for us,â she cried,
turning fiercely upon me.
There was accusation in her manner, and I shrugged my
shoulders in token that I was not guilty of the unknown crime
imputed to me.
âKnow, O White Man, that it is because of thy kind,
because of all white men, that my man and I have no meat in our
old age and sit without tobacco in the cold.â
âNay,â Ebbits said gravely, with a stricter sense
of justice.Â  âWrong has been done us, it be true; but
the white men did not mean the wrong.â
âWhere be Moklan?â she demanded.Â 
âWhere be thy strong son, Moklan, and the fish he was ever
willing to bring that you might eat?â
The old man shook his head.
âAnd where be Bidarshik, thy strong son?Â  Ever was
he a mighty hunter, and ever did he bring thee the good back-fat
and the sweet dried tongues of the moose and the caribou.Â  I
see no back-fat and no sweet dried tongues.Â  Your stomach is
full with emptiness through the days, and it is for a man of a
very miserable and lying people to give you to eat.â
âNay,â old Ebbits interposed in kindliness,
âthe white manâs is not a lying people.Â  The
white man speaks true.Â  Always does the white man speak
true.âÂ  He paused, casting about him for words
wherewith to temper the severity of what he was about to
say.Â  âBut the white man speaks true in different
ways.Â  To-day he speaks true one way, to-morrow he speaks
true another way, and there is no understanding him nor his
way.â
âTo-day speak true one way, to-morrow speak true another
way, which is to lie,â was Zillaâs dictum.
âThere is no understanding the white man,â Ebbits
went on doggedly.
The meat, and the tea, and the tobacco seemed to have brought
him back to life, and he gripped tighter hold of the idea behind
his age-bleared eyes.Â  He straightened up somewhat.Â 
His voice lost its querulous and whimpering note, and became
strong and positive.Â  He turned upon me with dignity, and
addressed me as equal addresses equal.
âThe white manâs eyes are not shut,â he
began.Â  âThe white man sees all things, and thinks
greatly, and is very wise.Â  But the white man of one day is
not the white man of next day, and there is no understanding
him.Â  He does not do things always in the same way.Â 
And what way his next way is to be, one cannot know.Â  Always
does the Indian do the one thing in the one way.Â  Always
does the moose come down from the high mountains when the winter
is here.Â  Always does the salmon come in the spring when the
ice has gone out of the river.Â  Always does everything do
all things in the same way, and the Indian knows and
understands.Â  But the white man does not do all things in
the same way, and the Indian does not know nor understand.
âTobacco be very good.Â  It be food to the hungry
man.Â  It makes the strong man stronger, and the angry man to
forget that he is angry.Â  Also is tobacco of value.Â  It
is of very great value.Â  The Indian gives one large salmon
for one leaf of tobacco, and he chews the tobacco for a long
time.Â  It is the juice of the tobacco that is good.Â 
When it runs down his throat it makes him feel good inside.Â 
But the white man!Â  When his mouth is full with the juice,
what does he do?Â  That juice, that juice of great value, he
spits it out in the snow and it is lost.Â  Does the white man
like tobacco?Â  I do not know.Â  But if he likes tobacco,
why does he spit out its value and lose it in the snow?Â  It
is a great foolishness and without understanding.â
He ceased, puffed at the pipe, found that it was out, and
passed it over to Zilla, who took the sneer at the white man off
her lips in order to pucker them about the pipe-stem.Â 
Ebbits seemed sinking back into his senility with the tale
untold, and I demanded:
âWhat of thy sons, Moklan and Bidarshik?Â  And why
is it that you and your old woman are without meat at the end of
your years?â
He roused himself as from sleep, and straightened up with an
effort.
âIt is not good to steal,â he said.Â 
âWhen the dog takes your meat you beat the dog with a
club.Â  Such is the law.Â  It is the law the man gave to
the dog, and the dog must live to the law, else will it suffer
the pain of the club.Â  When man takes your meat, or your
canoe, or your wife, you kill that man.Â  That is the law,
and it is a good law.Â  It is not good to steal, wherefore it
is the law that the man who steals must die.Â  Whoso breaks
the law must suffer hurt.Â  It is a great hurt to
die.â
âBut if you kill the man, why do you not kill the
dog?â I asked.
Old Ebbits looked at me in childlike wonder, while Zilla
sneered openly at the absurdity of my question.
âIt is the way of the white man,â Ebbits mumbled
with an air of resignation.
âIt is the foolishness of the white man,â snapped
Zilla.
âThen let old Ebbits teach the white man wisdom,â
I said softly.
âThe dog is not killed, because it must pull the sled of
the man.Â  No man pulls another manâs sled, wherefore
the man is killed.â
âOh,â I murmured.
âThat is the law,â old Ebbits went on.Â 
âNow listen, O White Man, and I will tell you of a great
foolishness.Â  There is an Indian.Â  His name is
Mobits.Â  From white man he steals two pounds of flour.Â 
What does the white man do?Â  Does he beat Mobits?Â 
No.Â  Does he kill Mobits?Â  No. What does he do to
Mobits?Â  I will tell you, O White Man.Â  He has a
house.Â  He puts Mobits in that house.Â  The roof is
good.Â  The walls are thick.Â  He makes a fire that
Mobits may be warm.Â  He gives Mobits plenty grub to
eat.Â  It is good grub.Â  Never in his all days does
Mobits eat so good grub.Â  There is bacon, and bread, and
beans without end.Â  Mobits have very good time.
âThere is a big lock on door so that Mobits does not run
away.Â  This also is a great foolishness.Â  Mobits will
not run away.Â  All the time is there plenty grub in that
place, and warm blankets, and a big fire.Â  Very foolish to
run away.Â  Mobits is not foolish.Â  Three months Mobits
stop in that place.Â  He steal two pounds of flour.Â  For
that, white man take plenty good care of him.Â  Mobits eat
many pounds of flour, many pounds of sugar, of bacon, of beans
without end.Â  Also, Mobits drink much tea.Â  After three
months white man open door and tell Mobits he must go.Â 
Mobits does not want to go.Â  He is like dog that is fed long
time in one place.Â  He want to stay in that place, and the
white man must drive Mobits away.Â  So Mobits come back to
this village, and he is very fat.Â  That is the white
manâs way, and there is no understanding it.Â  It is a
foolishness, a great foolishness.â
âBut thy sons?â I insisted.Â  âThy very
strong sons and thine old-age hunger?â
âThere was Moklan,â Ebbits began.
âA strong man,â interrupted the mother.Â 
âHe could dip paddle all of a day and night and never stop
for the need of rest.Â  He was wise in the way of the salmon
and in the way of the water.Â  He was very wise.â
âThere was Moklan,â Ebbits repeated, ignoring the
interruption.Â  âIn the spring, he went down the Yukon
with the young men to trade at Cambell Fort.Â  There is a
post there, filled with the goods of the white man, and a trader
whose name is Jones.Â  Likewise is there a white manâs
medicine man, what you call missionary.Â  Also is there bad
water at Cambell Fort, where the Yukon goes slim like a maiden,
and the water is fast, and the currents rush this way and that
and come together, and there are whirls and sucks, and always are
the currents changing and the face of the water changing, so at
any two times it is never the same.Â  Moklan is my son,
wherefore he is brave manââ
âWas not my father brave man?â Zilla demanded.
âThy father was brave man,â Ebbits acknowledged,
with the air of one who will keep peace in the house at any
cost.Â  âMoklan is thy son and mine, wherefore he is
brave.Â  Mayhap, because of thy very brave father, Moklan is
too brave.Â  It is like when too much water is put in the pot
it spills over.Â  So too much bravery is put into Moklan, and
the bravery spills over.
âThe young men are much afraid of the bad water at
Cambell Fort.Â  But Moklan is not afraid.Â  He laughs
strong, Ho! ho! and he goes forth into the bad water.Â  But
where the currents come together the canoe is turned over.Â 
A whirl takes Moklan by the legs, and he goes around and around,
and down and down, and is seen no more.â
âAi! ai!â wailed Zilla.Â  âCrafty and
wise was he, and my first-born!â
âI am the father of Moklan,â Ebbits said, having
patiently given the woman space for her noise.Â  âI get
into canoe and journey down to Cambell Fort to collect the
debt!â
âDebt!â interrupted.Â  âWhat
debt?â
âThe debt of Jones, who is chief trader,â came the
answer.Â  âSuch is the law of travel in a strange
country.â
I shook my head in token of my ignorance, and Ebbits looked
compassion at me, while Zilla snorted her customary contempt.
âLook you, O White Man,â he said.Â  âIn
thy camp is a dog that bites.Â  When the dog bites a man, you
give that man a present because you are sorry and because it is
thy dog.Â  You make payment.Â  Is it not so?Â  Also,
if you have in thy country bad hunting, or bad water, you must
make payment.Â  It is just.Â  It is the law.Â  Did
not my fatherâs brother go over into the Tanana Country and
get killed by a bear?Â  And did not the Tanana tribe pay my
father many blankets and fine furs?Â  It was just.Â  It
was bad hunting, and the Tanana people made payment for the bad
hunting.
âSo I, Ebbits, journeyed down to Cambell Fort to collect
the debt.Â  Jones, who is chief trader, looked at me, and he
laughed.Â  He made great laughter, and would not give
payment.Â  I went to the medicine-man, what you call
missionary, and had large talk about the bad water and the
payment that should be mine.Â  And the missionary made talk
about other things.Â  He talk about where Moklan has gone,
now he is dead.Â  There be large fires in that place, and if
missionary make true talk, I know that Moklan will be cold no
more.Â  Also the missionary talk about where I shall go when
I am dead.Â  And he say bad things.Â  He say that I am
blind.Â  Which is a lie.Â  He say that I am in great
darkness.Â  Which is a lie.Â  And I say that the day come
and the night come for everybody just the same, and that in my
village it is no more dark than at Cambell Fort.Â  Also, I
say that darkness and light and where we go when we die be
different things from the matter of payment of just debt for bad
water.Â  Then the missionary make large anger, and call me
bad names of darkness, and tell me to go away.Â  And so I
come back from Cambell Fort, and no payment has been made, and
Moklan is dead, and in my old age I am without fish and
meat.â
âBecause of the white man,â said Zilla.
âBecause of the white man,â Ebbits
concurred.Â  âAnd other things because of the white
man.Â  There was Bidarshik.Â  One way did the white man
deal with him; and yet another way for the same thing did the
white man deal with Yamikan.Â  And first must I tell you of
Yamikan, who was a young man of this village and who chanced to
kill a white man.Â  It is not good to kill a man of another
people.Â  Always is there great trouble.Â  It was not the
fault of Yamikan that he killed the white man.Â  Yamikan
spoke always soft words and ran away from wrath as a dog from a
stick.Â  But this white man drank much whiskey, and in the
night-time came to Yamikanâs house and made much
fight.Â  Yamikan cannot run away, and the white man tries to
kill him.Â  Yamikan does not like to die, so he kills the
white man.
âThen is all the village in great trouble.Â  We are
much afraid that we must make large payment to the white
manâs people, and we hide our blankets, and our furs, and
all our wealth, so that it will seem that we are poor people and
can make only small payment.Â  After long time white men
come.Â  They are soldier white men, and they take Yamikan
away with them.Â  His mother make great noise and throw ashes
in her hair, for she knows Yamikan is dead.Â  And all the
village knows that Yamikan is dead, and is glad that no payment
is asked.
âThat is in the spring when the ice has gone out of the
river.Â  One year go by, two years go by.Â  It is
spring-time again, and the ice has gone out of the river.Â 
And then Yamikan, who is dead, comes back to us, and he is not
dead, but very fat, and we know that he has slept warm and had
plenty grub to eat.Â  He has much fine clothes and is all the
same white man, and he has gathered large wisdom so that he is
very quick head man in the village.
âAnd he has strange things to tell of the way of the
white man, for he has seen much of the white man and done a great
travel into the white manâs country.Â  First place,
soldier white men take him down the river long way.Â  All the
way do they take him down the river to the end, where it runs
into a lake which is larger than all the land and large as the
sky.Â  I do not know the Yukon is so big river, but Yamikan
has seen with his own eyes.Â  I do not think there is a lake
larger than all the land and large as the sky, but Yamikan has
seen.Â  Also, he has told me that the waters of this lake be
salt, which is a strange thing and beyond understanding.
âBut the White Man knows all these marvels for himself,
so I shall not weary him with the telling of them.Â  Only
will I tell him what happened to Yamikan.Â  The white man
give Yamikan much fine grub.Â  All the time does Yamikan eat,
and all the time is there plenty more grub.Â  The white man
lives under the sun, so said Yamikan, where there be much warmth,
and animals have only hair and no fur, and the green things grow
large and strong and become flour, and beans, and potatoes.Â 
And under the sun there is never famine.Â  Always is there
plenty grub.Â  I do not know.Â  Yamikan has said.
âAnd here is a strange thing that befell Yamikan.Â 
Never did the white man hurt him.Â  Only did they give him
warm bed at night and plenty fine grub.Â  They take him
across the salt lake which is big as the sky.Â  He is on
white manâs fire-boat, what you call steamboat, only he is
on boat maybe twenty times bigger than steamboat on Yukon.Â 
Also, it is made of iron, this boat, and yet does it not
sink.Â  This I do not understand, but Yamikan has said,
âI have journeyed far on the iron boat; behold! I am still
alive.âÂ  It is a white manâs soldier-boat with
many soldier men upon it.
âAfter many sleeps of travel, a long, long time, Yamikan
comes to a land where there is no snow.Â  I cannot believe
this.Â  It is not in the nature of things that when winter
comes there shall be no snow.Â  But Yamikan has seen.Â 
Also have I asked the white men, and they have said yes, there is
no snow in that country.Â  But I cannot believe, and now I
ask you if snow never come in that country.Â  Also, I would
hear the name of that country.Â  I have heard the name
before, but I would hear it again, if it be the sameâthus
will I know if I have heard lies or true talk.â
Old Ebbits regarded me with a wistful face.Â  He would
have the truth at any cost, though it was his desire to retain
his faith in the marvel he had never seen.
âYes,â I answered, âit is true talk that you
have heard.Â  There is no snow in that country, and its name
is California.â
âCal-ee-forn-ee-yeh,â he mumbled twice and thrice,
listening intently to the sound of the syllables as they fell
from his lips.Â  He nodded his head in confirmation.Â 
âYes, it is the same country of which Yamikan made
talk.â
I recognized the adventure of Yamikan as one likely to occur
in the early days when Alaska first passed into the possession of
the United States.Â  Such a murder case, occurring before the
instalment of territorial law and officials, might well have been
taken down to the United States for trial before a Federal
court.
âWhen Yamikan is in this country where there is no
snow,â old Ebbits continued, âhe is taken to large
house where many men make much talk.Â  Long time men
talk.Â  Also many questions do they ask Yamikan.Â  By and
by they tell Yamikan he have no more trouble.Â  Yamikan does
not understand, for never has he had any trouble.Â  All the
time have they given him warm place to sleep and plenty grub.
âBut after that they give him much better grub, and they
give him money, and they take him many places in white
manâs country, and he see many strange things which are
beyond the understanding of Ebbits, who is an old man and has not
journeyed far.Â  After two years, Yamikan comes back to this
village, and he is head man, and very wise until he dies.
âBut before he dies, many times does he sit by my fire
and make talk of the strange things he has seen.Â  And
Bidarshik, who is my son, sits by the fire and listens; and his
eyes are very wide and large because of the things he
hears.Â  One night, after Yamikan has gone home, Bidarshik
stands up, so, very tall, and he strikes his chest with his fist,
and says, âWhen I am a man, I shall journey in far places,
even to the land where there is no snow, and see things for
myself.ââ
âAlways did Bidarshik journey in far places,â
Zilla interrupted proudly.
âIt be true,â Ebbits assented gravely.Â 
âAnd always did he return to sit by the fire and hunger for
yet other and unknown far places.â
âAnd always did he remember the salt lake as big as the
sky and the country under the sun where there is no snow,â
quoth Zilla.
âAnd always did he say, âWhen I have the full
strength of a man, I will go and see for myself if the talk of
Yamikan be true talk,ââ said Ebbits.
âBut there was no way to go to the white manâs
country,â said Zilla.
âDid he not go down to the salt lake that is big as the
sky?â Ebbits demanded.
âAnd there was no way for him across the salt
lake,â said Zilla.
âSave in the white manâs fire-boat which is of
iron and is bigger than twenty steamboats on the Yukon,â
said Ebbits.Â  He scowled at Zilla, whose withered lips were
again writhing into speech, and compelled her to silence.Â 
âBut the white man would not let him cross the salt lake in
the fire-boat, and he returned to sit by the fire and hunger for
the country under the sun where there is no
snow.ââ
âYet on the salt lake had he seen the fire-boat of iron
that did not sink,â cried out Zilla the irrepressible.
âAy,â said Ebbits, âand he saw that Yamikan
had made true talk of the things he had seen.Â  But there was
no way for Bidarshik to journey to the white manâs land
under the sun, and he grew sick and weary like an old man and
moved not away from the fire.Â  No longer did he go forth to
kill meatââ
âAnd no longer did he eat the meat placed before
him,â Zilla broke in.Â  âHe would shake his head
and say, âOnly do I care to eat the grub of the white man
and grow fat after the manner of Yamikan.ââ
âAnd he did not eat the meat,â Ebbits went
on.Â  âAnd the sickness of Bidarshik grew into a great
sickness until I thought he would die.Â  It was not a
sickness of the body, but of the head.Â  It was a sickness of
desire.Â  I, Ebbits, who am his father, make a great
think.Â  I have no more sons and I do not want Bidarshik to
die.Â  It is a head-sickness, and there is but one way to
make it well.Â  Bidarshik must journey across the lake as
large as the sky to the land where there is no snow, else will he
die.Â  I make a very great think, and then I see the way for
Bidarshik to go.
âSo, one night when he sits by the fire, very sick, his
head hanging down, I say, âMy son, I have learned the way
for you to go to the white manâs land.âÂ  He
looks at me, and his face is glad.Â  âGo,â I say,
âeven as Yamikan went.âÂ  But Bidarshik is sick
and does not understand.Â  âGo forth,â I say,
âand find a white man, and, even as Yamikan, do you kill
that white man.Â  Then will the soldier white men come and
get you, and even as they took Yamikan will they take you across
the salt lake to the white manâs land.Â  And then, even
as Yamikan, will you return very fat, your eyes full of the
things you have seen, your head filled with wisdom.â
âAnd Bidarshik stands up very quick, and his hand is
reaching out for his gun.Â  âWhere do you go?â I
ask.Â  âTo kill the white man,â he says.Â 
And I see that my words have been good in the ears of Bidarshik
and that he will grow well again.Â  Also do I know that my
words have been wise.
âThere is a white man come to this village.Â  He
does not seek after gold in the ground, nor after furs in the
forest.Â  All the time does he seek after bugs and
flies.Â  He does not eat the bugs and flies, then why does he
seek after them?Â  I do not know.Â  Only do I know that
he is a funny white man.Â  Also does he seek after the eggs
of birds.Â  He does not eat the eggs.Â  All that is
inside he takes out, and only does he keep the shell.Â 
Eggshell is not good to eat.Â  Nor does he eat the eggshells,
but puts them away in soft boxes where they will not break.Â 
He catch many small birds.Â  But he does not eat the
birds.Â  He takes only the skins and puts them away in
boxes.Â  Also does he like bones.Â  Bones are not good to
